author: dock_boss
content:
I am currently drafting up the SRS doc for the JSON-RPC API, but I am still new to the community so I want to make sure I am on the right track. 
Does the following paragraph accurately summarize the scope of the API?

author: dock_boss
content: ```The Ethereum execution layer JSON-RPC API will provide the basis for all external interaction with the Ethereum blockchain. The interactions with the Ethereum network can be divided into four categories. Transferring ETH, ERC-20 tokens, and ERC-721 tokens to different accounts or smart contracts. Pulling network, block, and transaction data from the blockchain. Allowing users to interact with and deploy Ethereum smart contracts. Lastly the JSON-RPC API **SHOULD** allow the sending and receiving of current client information and statuses. ```

author: sky.cactus
content:
> The interactions with the Ethereum network can be divided into four categories. Transferring ETH, ERC-20 tokens, and ERC-721 tokens to different accounts or smart contracts.
This isn't quite right.  This class of interactions with the Ethereum network are "transfer ETH, deploy contracts, execute contracts".

author: sky.cactus
content: Tokens are a subset of the latter two and not really relevant for this level of discussion.

author: sky.cactus
content: What does "sending of current client information and statuses" mean?  Seems like that should be read-only.

author: sky.cactus
content: Also, I think there is another category for "administrative tasks", though personally I think that should occur at a different endpoint and on the JSON-RPC API.

author: dock_boss
content: I was trying to describe the endpoints that are focused towards people running nodes like eth_submitHashrate, eth_submitWork, and eth_syncing. Are these part of the administrative tasks?
